content: The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students by offering productive activities during after school hours. The findings in the "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" highlight the increased social risks faced by today's youth, including spending more unsupervised time alone and being at higher risk of violence during after school hours. The goals of the Act include increasing academic success, improving various skills, promoting safe environments, preparing for workforce participation, and providing alternatives to negative activities. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "school" refers to public kindergarten, elementary, or secondary schools. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 6. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary can award grants to schools for carrying out activities in section 7(a). SEC. 7. AUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES; REQUIREMENTS. Each school receiving a grant under this Act must conduct at least 2 of the following activities: mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additionally, schools may choose to implement drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. The school must provide drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities after regular school hours. Activities should reflect the specific needs of the population and be carried out in a designated school building or public facility. The school must provide activities that reflect the specific needs of the population and be carried out in a designated school building or public facility. The school is encouraged to request volunteers, donations of computer equipment, and work with state and local park and recreation agencies for additional support. Additionally, communities can serve as mentors or assist in other ways to avoid duplication of activities under this Act. SEC. 8. APPLICATIONS. Each school seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the goals will be met, collaborative efforts, administration of activities, and utilization of resources. The application for the grant must involve various stakeholders and detail how activities will be administered, avoid duplication, utilize funding sources, and secure non-Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
